passage.title: The Inheritance
passage.content:
The envelope arrived three weeks after Grandmother's funeral, addressed to Lily Chen in handwriting she would have recognized anywhere—thin, elegant loops that Grandmother had spent her whole life perfecting.

Inside was a single key and a note: 'The workshop. Everything there is yours now.'

Lily had never been allowed in Grandmother's workshop. As a child, she'd pressed her face against the frosted glass window, catching glimpses of shapes and shadows, watching Grandmother's silhouette move with purpose through the space. The door was always locked, and whenever Lily asked what was inside, Grandmother would only say, 'Someday.'

Now someday had arrived, and Lily wasn't sure she wanted it.

She stood outside the workshop for fifteen minutes, key in hand, making excuses. The weather was too cold. She hadn't slept well. She should wait for her mother. But the real reason, the one she wouldn't admit even to herself, was simpler: opening that door would mean Grandmother was truly gone.

As long as the workshop remained locked, there was still a secret between them. Still something left to discover. Opening it felt like reading the last page of a book she never wanted to end.

Finally, her frozen fingers found the lock.

The workshop was smaller than she'd imagined—barely larger than a walk-in closet. But every surface held treasures: jade figurines, half-finished embroidery, delicate paper cuttings, and stacks of notebooks filled with Grandmother's handwriting. On the workbench sat a partially completed sculpture of a crane, its wings outstretched, its head turned as if listening.

Lily lifted one of the notebooks and found it wasn't recipes or finances, as she'd assumed. It was drawings—hundreds of them—dated over sixty years. And scattered throughout, dozens of them showed a little girl with two pigtails and a curious expression, peering through a frosted window.

Grandmother had been drawing her. All those years, while Lily had watched from outside, Grandmother had watched right back.

At the bottom of the notebook, on the very last page, Grandmother had written: 'She has my eyes, and my restlessness. When the time is right, she will understand why some doors must stay closed—until the person on the other side is ready to walk through.'

Lily's hands trembled as she set down the notebook. She'd always assumed Grandmother kept her out to protect the workshop. But that wasn't it at all. Grandmother had been protecting something far more fragile: the moment when Lily would be old enough to receive not just the objects, but their meaning.

Lily picked up the unfinished crane. Its eyes were still hollow, waiting. She found Grandmother's carving tools right where they'd always been, arranged with the precision of someone who expected to return.

She didn't know how to carve. But she knew that Grandmother had once stood exactly here, just as uncertain, facing her own first blank piece of jade.

Lily lifted a tool and began.

Some inheritances aren't given. They're accepted—when the person is ready.

questions.stem: Lily hesitates to unlock the workshop primarily because she:

mcqOptions.text: Fears that entering will make her grandmother's death feel final
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! The text states 'opening that door would mean Grandmother was truly gone.' Lily delays because the locked door maintains a connection to her grandmother.

mcqOptions.text: Does not know how to use the key in the lock
mcqOptions.feedback: There's no mechanical problem—'her frozen fingers found the lock' and it opens. Her hesitation is emotional, not practical.

mcqOptions.text: Is worried the workshop will be disappointing
mcqOptions.feedback: Lily doesn't fear disappointment—she fears finality. Her concern is emotional (losing connection to Grandmother), not about the workshop's contents.

mcqOptions.text: Believes she was not meant to receive the key
mcqOptions.feedback: Grandmother clearly intended Lily to have it ('Everything there is yours now'). Lily doesn't question the rightness of receiving it—she struggles with the emotional weight of using it.

hints.content: What are the 'excuses' Lily makes? What is the 'real reason' she won't admit?
What would opening the door 'mean' to Lily?
Opening it 'would mean Grandmother was truly gone'—finality is what she fears.

questions.stem: Lily compares opening the workshop to 'reading the last page of a book' because:

mcqOptions.text: Her grandmother was a writer who kept stories there
mcqOptions.feedback: The workshop contains art and crafts, not stories. The book comparison is metaphorical—about endings—not literal about the workshop's contents.

mcqOptions.text: She expects to find books inside the workshop
mcqOptions.feedback: This interprets the metaphor literally. Lily doesn't expect books—she's using the metaphor to express her fear of finality, not describing contents.

mcqOptions.text: Once done, there will be nothing left to discover about her grandmother
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Lily worries that opening the workshop uses up the last mystery—'still something left to discover.' Like finishing a book, once done, the journey ends.

mcqOptions.text: She prefers to skip to endings rather than experience things fully
mcqOptions.feedback: The OPPOSITE is implied—Lily doesn't WANT the ending. She says it's 'a book she never wanted to end.' She's avoiding the end, not seeking it.

textEvidence.quoteHint: last page of a book she never wanted to end

hints.content: What happens when you read the last page of a book?
What is Lily saying she doesn't want to happen with her connection to Grandmother?
Last page = story ends = nothing more to discover. She wants the 'story' with Grandmother to continue.

questions.stem: Grandmother's motivation for keeping Lily out of the workshop all those years was to:

mcqOptions.text: Test whether Lily would respect boundaries
mcqOptions.feedback: This wasn't a test of obedience. Grandmother's note shows she was waiting for readiness, not evaluating Lily's behaviour.

mcqOptions.text: Maintain privacy for her secret artistic practice
mcqOptions.feedback: Grandmother wasn't hiding that she made art—Lily could see her through the window. The locked door wasn't about secrecy; it was about timing the revelation.

mcqOptions.text: Keep her valuable art pieces safe from damage
mcqOptions.feedback: Lily initially 'assumed Grandmother kept her out to protect the workshop'—but the text says 'that wasn't it at all.' The protection was about timing, not security.

mcqOptions.text: Wait until Lily was emotionally ready to receive the inheritance's meaning
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Grandmother wrote that 'some doors must stay closed—until the person on the other side is ready to walk through.' She was waiting for Lily's readiness, not protecting objects.

textEvidence.quoteHint: until the person on the other side is ready

hints.content: What did Lily first ASSUME about why Grandmother locked the door?
What does Grandmother's note say about when doors should open?
'Ready to walk through'—Grandmother was protecting the moment, not the objects.

questions.stem: Lily's discovery that Grandmother drew her 'watching from outside' reveals that Grandmother was motivated by:

mcqOptions.text: Deep attention and love for Lily throughout the years
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Grandmother wasn't ignoring Lily—she was watching back, documenting her granddaughter. The drawings show loving attention across sixty years.

mcqOptions.text: Amusement at Lily's curiosity about the workshop
mcqOptions.feedback: Grandmother's note is tender and wise, not amused. She writes about Lily having her 'eyes' and 'restlessness'—this is recognition and love, not entertainment.

mcqOptions.text: A desire to record memories for her own reference
mcqOptions.feedback: The drawings weren't just personal records—they were LEFT for Lily to find. The note addresses Lily directly. This was communication, not just documentation.

mcqOptions.text: Frustration that Lily would not leave her alone
mcqOptions.feedback: There's no frustration in the drawings or note. Grandmother describes Lily warmly ('my eyes, my restlessness') and prepared this inheritance thoughtfully.

hints.content: How many drawings of Lily did Grandmother make?
What does creating 'dozens' of drawings over 'sixty years' suggest about attention?
Consistent attention over decades = deep, sustained love.

questions.stem: Lily's decision to pick up the carving tools at the end is motivated by:

mcqOptions.text: Obligation to finish the crane before showing anyone
mcqOptions.feedback: There's no mention of obligation or showing anyone. Lily's action is internal—about connection and continuation—not about completing a task for others.

mcqOptions.text: Anger that Grandmother left the crane unfinished
mcqOptions.feedback: There's no anger in this scene. Lily's trembling hands and careful actions show reverence and emotion, not frustration about the unfinished state.

mcqOptions.text: A desire to continue her grandmother's work and legacy
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! Lily imagines Grandmother 'once stood exactly here, just as uncertain' and chooses to begin where Grandmother left off. She's accepting and continuing the legacy.

mcqOptions.text: Confidence that she has inherited artistic talent
mcqOptions.feedback: The text says 'She didn't know how to carve' and imagines Grandmother being 'just as uncertain' at first. This isn't confidence—it's courage despite uncertainty.

textEvidence.quoteHint: Grandmother had once stood exactly here

nswSelectiveReading.questionFunction: Interpret meaning of character's final action

hints.content: What does Lily imagine about Grandmother before beginning?
Does Lily feel skilled or uncertain? Why does she begin anyway?
She begins 'just as uncertain' as Grandmother once was—continuing a legacy, not demonstrating skill.

questions.stem: The final line—'Some inheritances aren't given. They're accepted—when the person is ready'—suggests that Lily's motivation throughout was actually about:

mcqOptions.text: Waiting for permission from other family members
mcqOptions.feedback: Lily already had permission (the key, the note). The 'readiness' is internal—emotional maturity—not about getting others' approval.

mcqOptions.text: Proving to herself that she deserved the inheritance
mcqOptions.feedback: The story isn't about deserving or earning. 'Accepted—when ready' is about emotional capacity, not worthiness. Lily never questions whether she deserves it.

mcqOptions.text: Understanding the monetary value of the objects
mcqOptions.feedback: The passage explicitly contrasts objects with 'meaning' ('not just the objects, but their meaning'). The inheritance is emotional and spiritual, not financial.

mcqOptions.text: Reaching a point of emotional readiness to receive what was always offered
mcqOptions.feedback: Correct! The inheritance was always there (Grandmother intended it). Lily's journey was about becoming READY—not about earning or receiving something new, but about being able to accept it.

nswSelectiveReading.questionFunction: Evaluate how final statement illuminates character journey

hints.content: Did Lily ever doubt that the inheritance was MEANT for her?
What changed between Lily hesitating at the door and Lily picking up the tools?
The inheritance was always hers—what changed was her READINESS to accept it.
